meta.title: American Crusade: Our Fight to Stay Free
meta.author: Pete Hegseth

parts.title: Our American Crusade: Rallying Against the Left
parts.body: "Our American Crusade" delves into the deep political divide in America after the 2016 election, drawing on a historical narrative to rally support against leftist ideologies blamed for undermining the nation's soul and institutions. The author calls for an American Crusade, likening it to historical crusades and revolutions as a defense against what is perceived as an existential threat posed by the Left. The piece contrasts two immigrant perspectives, highlighting a divergence in patriotism and gratitude towards America. It emphasizes extreme loyalty and champions Trump’s presidency as critical for preserving America's essence.**

parts.title: Understanding Americanism and Nationalism
parts.body: Initially, Pete Hegseth dismissed Donald Trump's "America first" slogan as isolationism, reminding him of the America First Committee before WWII. Hegseth believed it lacked foreign policy substance. Yet, with Trump's nomination, Hegseth's stance changed, recognizing "America first" as pivotal for US actions, ensuring US strength amidst global threats. Trump's presidency emphasized evaluating actions through an America-first lens, challenging elitists while resonating with patriots. Americanism emerges as Hegseth's antidote to leftism, centering on the US founding ideals. Americanism is defined as allegiance to individual freedom and equal justice, aligning with American nationalism. The enemies of America attack these ideas, perverting nationalism as racist to undermine national sovereignty. Exploring history and inherent human flaws, Hegseth stresses Americanism as the cornerstone of progress, from historical civil rights advancements to modern technological developments. The challenges lie in preserving core principles, crucial against leftist cultural and policy attacks.

parts.title: Founding Documents and Ideals vs. Leftist Agenda
parts.body: ## American Ideals vs. Leftist Reality The difference between the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution is crucial. While both are linked, the Declaration provides America’s soul, proclaiming principles like God-given rights and the right to alter government. In contrast, the Constitution offers the structure to uphold those ideals. Leftists disregard the Declaration, seeking a “living Constitution” that can justify their control and suppress freedoms like the Second Amendment. American founders ensured checks against majority rule to protect individual rights. Contrastingly, leftists crave "democracy" to quickly reshape society.

parts.title: Cultural Shift in Political Dynamics
parts.body: Current cultural conflict in the US Democratic party signals a struggle between older political power, represented by figures like Nancy Pelosi, and the rising influence of leftist figures like AOC and Bernie Sanders. While Pelosi has votes in Congress, she lacks the appeal of the younger audience who resonate with socialist rhetoric. This is seen as a cultural shift where today's political establishment might not represent the soul of tomorrow. The conversation on leftism versus individual freedom highlights the belief that collectivism and outdated welfare policies don't work, exemplified by the Soviet Union's collapse. Critics argue that a government-centered approach stifles personal initiative and that true empowerment lies in personal freedom and entrepreneurship. The failures of socialistic systems point out that despite good intentions, overreliance on government leads to inefficiencies and fosters a state of dependency.

parts.title: NATO's Role and Criticism in Afghanistan
parts.body: When I served in Afghanistan under a NATO mission, I was with the International Security Assistance Force (ISAF). Wearing an American flag on one shoulder and an ISAF patch on the other became a joke; as other troops from fifty countries rarely engaged in combat compared to US troops. At ISAF headquarters in Kabul it was clear this was "the United States’s war" with little support from allies. Their political limitations on the battlefield meant others did not or could not fight. NATO seemed more like a defense arrangement for Europe, funded largely by the US, rather than a true alliance. In Afghanistan, it felt like America was alone in combat, and the larger NATO alliance did little when Russia, led by Putin, invaded Crimea. Today's NATO seems like a distraction, with European countries not interested in rebuilding militaries post-World War II. Critics argue it's still essential in dealing with an aggressive Russia, claiming NATO is vital for like-minded countries. But the perception on the ground was its limitations and the disparity in combat contributions.

parts.title: Socialism: Misleading Promises vs. Capitalism
parts.body: Socialism is equated to taxing hard-working individuals more, redistributing their earnings to others via government control. The author argues that socialism could allure young people due to misleading notions of "economic justice". Schools might not highlight capitalism's merits while presenting socialist ideas favorably, driving a false narrative of fairness interpreted by politicians and educators. A discussion with Gunner uses rubber duckies to illustrate issues like excessive production and overpricing affecting supply and demand. The talk evolves into political economy, observing how governments impact businesses and ultimately skew a free-market system towards socialism.

parts.title: Elitism and Political Correctness
parts.body:
Elitism and Political Correctness

Vice President-elect Pence called Pete Hegseth to arrange a meeting with President-elect Trump, considering him for a role as Secretary of Veterans Affairs. Despite Pete's previous criticism of Trump, his advocacy for veterans' issues had caught Trump's attention. During the meeting at Trump Tower, Trump humorously referenced Pete's earlier support for Marco Rubio, nicknaming him "Little Marco." Pete then complimented Trump on his nickname for Elizabeth Warren, "Pocahontas", and Trump explained his reasoning as a marketer. Trump's comments and approach highlight his strategy against political correctness, which he believes limits free speech and maintains power for an elite class.

parts.title: Reclaiming Control from Elites
parts.body: The elites are seen as those who think they are better than others, using complex language to confuse and control. The media and tech oligarchies are criticized for promoting left-wing ideologies and silencing conservatives. This section highlights the hypocrisy of the elites, who want control through political correctness. When people are silenced or censored, like on social media, it's viewed as controlling speech to maintain elite power. The speaker encourages laughing at and mocking these controls to regain freedom. The chapter argues for rejecting elitism and political correctness, viewing them as forms of authoritarianism. It promotes free speech and questioning the narrative pushed by elites, urging people to follow Trump's example in standing against elitist values. Emphasizing American values and unity is contrasted against the divisive nature of political correctness. The text calls for empowering the "real elite," everyday Americans, against what is perceived as elitist ridicule.

parts.title: Understanding Esmatullah's Beliefs & The Threat of Islamism
parts.body: Esmatullah was an interpreter in Afghanistan during the author's deployment. Although Esmat was a regular Muslim, not a radical Islamist, he believed that Islam would rule the world due to high birth rates. Islamism, derived from the Quran, is perceived as a significant threat to freedom, being aggressive and evangelical. Many Westerners mistakenly view Islam as a "religion of peace," overlooking the aggressive nature of Islamism. In reality, while peaceful Muslims exist, Islamism seeks the domination of Islamic ideals globally. Islamism uses the beliefs of moderate Muslims to spread its radical agenda. Despite the presence of non-radical Muslims, Islamism is deeply rooted in the core teachings of Islam, making it difficult to separate from the moderate interpretation. Islamists aim to impose Islam on others, a mission reflecting Muhammad’s life and Quranic teachings. This poses a challenge as Islam doesn't have a "New Testament" equivalent, meaning no substantial reform shift akin to Christianity's transformation. Therefore, Islamism is not just religious but also a political system incompatible with any other. With Saudi Arabian funding, groups like the Muslim Brotherhood advance Islamist missions, posing significant challenges to Western freedoms.

parts.title: The Evolution and Defense of Western Civilization
parts.body: This passage delves into the concept of western civilization through the prism of Christianity's evolution and the ongoing battles it has faced. Initially, Christianity spread peacefully but, due to persecution, took a militaristic stance under Constantine the Great. The text contrasts Christianity and Islam, noting that while Christianity initially propagated through love and faith, Islam spread through jihad and warfare. By the 11th century, the imminent threat from Islam led to the Crusades as a defensive measure to protect Christian faith and territories. The piece also argues that leftists today would argue for "diplomacy" much like peaceful negotiations, ignoring the historical necessity of the Crusades. Leftists are portrayed as unwilling to accept the value of what Crusaders accomplished for the modern world, such as preserving Western civilization and ultimately enabling phenomena like the Protestant Reformation and the Renaissance. This sets the stage for the "American Crusade," encouraging readers to fight for Christian and American values.
